contentrichtext.text: {{no footnotes|date=February 2013}} [[File:Ada Adler.gif|thumb|150px|right|Ada Adler c. 1900.]] '''[[Ada (name)|Ada]] Sara Adler''' (1878–1946) was a [[Denmark|Danish]] [[classical scholar]] and [[librarian]]. She is best known for her critical, standard edition of the ''[[Suda]]'', which she published in 5 volumes (Leipzig, 1928–1938). She also contributed several articles to [[Pauly-Wissowa]]'s ''Realencyclopädie''. Her father's sister, Ellen Adler Bohr, was the mother of [[Niels Bohr]] and [[Harald Bohr]]. During World War II, she was evacuated to Sweden with other Danish Jews. She taught Greek in the Danish school in Lund. In 1916, she published a catalog of [[Greek language|Greek]] manuscripts in the [[Danish Royal Library|Royal Library]], [[Copenhagen]]. In 1931, she was awarded the [[Tagea Brandt Rejselegat]]. At the time of her death she had made substantial progress towards a first edition of the ''[[Etymologicum Genuinum]]'', a project continued under the direction of Klaus Alpers. == Works == *1916: ''Catalogue supplémentaire des manuscrits grecs de la Bibliothèque Royale de Copenhague''. *1917: ''[[Daniel Gotthilf Moldenhawer|D.
